column1: The must have and highly anticipated set for 2H2010 Technic fans and it is definitely the best Technic set I have owned as far as playability and functionality, only second to the 8455 Backhoe Loader from 2003.
column2: Funny thing is as of 7/15/2010 only UK Lego S@H had it available, it wasn't available in the USA, but Toys R Us had all the 2H2010 Technic sets available in my local TRU.
column3: Funny they would receive them before the Lego distribution center in the USA had it available to order.&nbsp
column4: This set rivals the 8275 RC Bulldozer from 2007 in terms of functionality.&nbsp
column5: It is a very large model when complete, but a very satisfying building experience and even when not playing with it, it looks excellent set on a shelf for display.&nbsp

column1: Pros: Tons of functions, complex satisfying building experience, looks very elegant much like a real-life excavator, rivals the 8294 Excavator from 2008 mainly because it is completely remote-controlled and has the needed 3rd linear actuator to operate the bucket tilt.
Cons: Not much here except for the high price, $199 US dollars is steep, but with all the power functions included I can see the price point being realistic.
column3: Power functions M-motors a little weak in operating the bucket tilt, boom raise and lower and the boom extension, but the motors for operating the forwards, backwards,&nbsp
column4: turning and rotating of the superstructure are very smooth and fast indeed.&nbsp
column5: Bucket seems a bit oversized as did the bucket for the 8294 Excavator, but Lego only seems to have 3 bucket sizes nowadays and it is the same one as on the 8265 Front-End Loader from 2009 and the front bucket on the 8455 Backhoe.

column1: In closing, this is a must have for any Technic collector.

bereft,"2010-08-07T18:32:46.1Z","Marvelous set","

The 8043 set is what 8275 (Motorized Bulldozer) should be in 2007. While having the same four motors Power Functions system (the only significant difference is using 4 M motors instead of 2 M + 2 XL) the Motorized Excavator are truly designed for action. It drives rather slowly, but tracks help to overcome significant obstacles, like house slippers. Due to very complicated co-axial drivetrain from motors to
column2: tracks excavator tends to turn left slightly while travelling a long distances, but it justifiable for the superstructure being able to rotate infinitely. Movements of boom, bucket and arm is quite jerky, but again, the number of gears (more than 10 for every function)and overall complexity of the structure make me forgive some playability imperfections. Al in all this set will definitely not going only to stand on the display shelf.&nbsp
column3: Building experience is quiet interesting as it all about gears. Co-axial drivetrain for the tracks and motor-switched gearbox for six functions being driven by three motors are the innovations of the decade, everything else we could see in other recent Technic models. Building process is not so exciting as in case of 8421 or 8880 sets, but also isn't boring, as it gives us a new idea of drivetrain complexity. In terms of parts this set will provide technic fan with 4 linear actuators, 4 motors, 2 IRs and a plenty of gears. Decorative panels are also in abundance.
column4: The price tag may seem ridiculous for the toy (more than 300 USD here in Belarus), but I think that over several years this set will share fate of 8421, 8285 and other successful sets of not so distant past. If you keen on Technic theme, buy it immediately. This set is surely the best LEGO Technic in recent 5-7 years and rivals such legends as 8880, 8480 and 8455.

column1:
joedreamliner787,"2010-09-23T00:00:48.737Z","For 200.00 bucks you can't go wrong with this incredible set.","This is set is incredible and has lots of new cool parts to use and despite the actuator problem lego has announced it's an issue and just call customer service and they will send you new ones. This is an incredible set and took me 5.5 hours to build and just take your time. 200.00 and it's worth every penny. Just make sure if you have the motorized bulldozer
you set the all the addresses differently on the remotes if you plan to play with both of them at the same time :-) (having a brother does that) It was fun to build and I'm 26 but hey it's challenges you and makes you so much more efficient in the real world as far as thinking outside the box! The only complaint I would have is that it is a slow moving machine going forward and backward and the bulldozer is much quicker. Pick it up because toys r us has them and grab 2 or 3 because they are running a special buy two sets get one free! I picked up three because in three years this set will triple in price and I will sell it on ebay new in the box and I'll have two.
",TRUE,5,5,5,5,5

adam85,"2010-09-03T08:15:20.403Z","Most complex Technic set","Despite the problems mentioned in some Lego forums I decided to buy this set.
The box is the same size as the 8258 Crane Truck. There are three instruction book. The building steps are very clear but you should look every step carefully and check the working features during the building because the functions easily can go wrong. The set has a lot of useful pieces: tons of gears (there are lot of clutch gear!) beams new and old panels, four M-motors, two receivers, two controller, four (!) linear actuators.
The build took me 7-8 hours. The building process is very interesting there weren't any boring part. The model is very complex. And you have to work in a small space (gearbox) which makes it hard and challenging. The gearbox is the most difficult part of the model. I advice to check every axle and gears moving freely before completing.
When I finished the model I was afraid that it won't work. But it works! The only problem is that the main arm (which powered by the double linear actuators) raise slowly, but it is not completely useless. The lowereing of the main arm is better. Other functions works fine.
The model is very playable so dont worry about that. I suggest you to buy this if you like large and complex Technic models.
",TRUE,5,5,5,5,5

column1: av8r1973,"2011-01-01T03:40:16.41Z","Wonderfully complex - great build and conversation piece","Interestingly, this set resulted in the purchase of a display shelf. My wife actually allowed this to be displayed in the living room!&nbsp
column2: That reflects the intricacy and detail that LEGO has infused into this wonderful kit.&nbsp
column3: It's a great conversation piece and visitors can't help but to play with it.&nbsp
column4: The kit is played with quite often and my daughters occasionally try to scoop up other bricks for fun.&nbsp
column5: Pros    Incredibly complex gearbox and power transfer to the tracks    360 degree spinning superstructure    Very realistic appearance, movement and even sounds (to a point)    Track operation is realistic, allowing it to climb over small obstacles    Cleverly disguised Power Functions components    B-model tracked loader is really cool and fast!    Impressive display of engineering and ingenuity in a ""toy""    Unique use of clutches to double the Power Functions utilityCons    M motor not powerful enough to drive two linear actuators to raise boom, even with no load. Should have used the XL motor for the boom.    Boom raises too slowly (motor issue and linear actuator design)    Cable routing from battery pack to motors could be much neater    Like other Technic kits, the B-model instructions are only available online    Price?    Bucket size is out of scale - it's a dozer bucket. &nbsp
column6: For the price, a narrower bucket could have been created and used on other LEGO kits    Boom is pretty wobbly, but it's a limitation of the components used and the friction fit of them all.        &nbsp
column7: Though I notice now that the Con list is longer than the Pro list, I also notice the severity of the Cons is pretty low. &nbsp
column8: A service pack is apparently available and I have requested one from LEGO. &nbsp
column9: This is a wonderful kit to assemble, disassemble, reassemble into the B-model and then reverse the process again. &nbsp
column10:
Loads of fun! I really hope Technic follows this up in 2011 with another equally impressive set.

UPDATE 1/3/11: I emailed LEGO regarding the service pack and got a very pleasant email reply that one was on its way.
column11:
I really do love LEGO customer service!

UPDATE 1/28/11: I received my service pack yesterday and was amazed.
column12: A letter was included that reads, ""Thanks for waiting! &nbsp
column13: We're pleased to enclose the replacement parts that you need to make the 'digging arm' of your Excavator 8043 as strong as it should be. &nbsp
column14: While we were testing the new pieces, we realised [sic] that there was another improvement we could make, so we're sending you an extra bag of pieces that should be included in the model at step 33 and 36 in the building instructions. &nbsp
column15: These new pieces may help your Excavator to move backwards and forwards more efficiently. &nbsp
column16: We hope you enjoy building this great set and thank you again for your patience. &nbsp
column18: Your LEGO Customer Service Team.""The bag included new actuators (look identical to the originals) and a few new axles. &nbsp
column19: I need to dedicate the time to dig into the heart of this beast and rebuild it. &nbsp
column20:
I love LEGO customer service!

UPDATE 1/29/11: Had to disassemble the entire model to get the modkit installed for the forward and backwards movement.
column25: I was actually able to pick up the 6 AA batteries that died trying to power the old actuators. &nbsp
column26: The lift speed is nearly as fast as the lowering speed. &nbsp

column1:
TheAB,"2010-12-31T10:09:55.21Z","Great Design but Low Playability // Overall a Very Good Set","

The 2010 Technic flagship model is a very good set. However The Lego Group pushed so much on its technical innovations that they really risked to ""
column5: "">bit off more than they could chew"".
column9:
"">Box/Instructions

Finally the instructions booklet comes in a plastic envelope together with a cardboard sheet to prevent wrinkles. The box is eco-friendly meaning a bit smaller than those of older flagship sets.

column1:
Parts

Major weakness here is the bucket (www.bricklink.com/catalogItem.asp?P=32030) which is clearly not an excavator but a front loader one. This economy doesn't look good on a flagship model.
On the positive side, we have quite a lot of Power Functions elements. It would have been nicer to have 2x XL and 2x M motors instead of 4x M motors and/or even 3x IR receivers. However this would have pushed up too much the retail price.
My set was the ""fixed"" version including the modified Linear Actuators (technicbricks.blogspot.com/2010/10/tbs-technuggets-12-inside-linear.html) for smoother functioning.

The build

Very good and challenging building experience. Following the instructions there is no issue in completing the model.

column2:
Low to poor playability. In the effort to increase the number of functions minimizing costs (which is ok since they would stop producing Technic models if they didn't make a profit) The Lego Group has come up with an underpowered motorized model.
Even with the Service Pack fix - that is new LAs and slighlty different building of left track trasmisison - the PF M motors can barely handle the weight of the model.

column1:
Summary

This is overall a very good set. You can clearly see the effort of TLG to improve the design of its Technic products and make it closer to the real models adding more details. Also it is appreciable the effort to increase the complexity of the functions, in particular coupling together Power Functions elements with clutches to multiply the number of functions per motor.
column2:
These are to me the main trends in the Lego Technic product developement:
1. More realistic Design. This is clear also in the 2H 2011 Technic sets 8071, 8109 and 8110.
2. Power Functions coupled with Clutches. This has been present already in 8297, 8258 e.g. and will be in 8110 with high complexity.

column1:
Bram,"2011-01-06T02:25:24.037Z","8043 tips, myths and facts","

When a set could bring an adult after 20 years of Lego absence..it must be something special. Well because it is.
column2: I bought the newer edition set with the updated LAs and instructions. I'd read about the earlier production having
column4: Even with the new updated LAs, few are still having problems. This is more to the builder's issue..not the set's
column5: The 8043 is an advanced model, it requires more than just simply following the booklet.
column7: building a smooth operating and powerful&nbsp
column8:
8043 not found on the booklet! :)
1. Watch the gears! Make sure when you insert the gears or when the gears are positioned between two objects (eg. beams), give a slight play/tolerance..and spin them to make sure they spin freely.
2. Align the universal joints on both ends of each axle. This will further reduce vibration when operating the dipper and bucket.
3. This is optional, use light silicone oil LIGHTLY on the gears, this reduces friction by A LOT. Silicone oil is safe for plastics, clear in color, when applied properly will not ruin the cleanliness of your LEGO.
4. Align the LAs on the boom when it's under load. You need to calibrate the gears so you have perfect alignment. This will lighten the load as the LAs are not 'forcing' against each other.
column9: If you've done the above 'tuning', all these myths below are busted.
column10:
The 8043 myths:
1. The M motor is not powerful enough for this model even with the updated LAs.
column11: Fact: this is a complete non sense! My 8043 performs admirably well. I can lift the boom with a small Technic 8047 mini excavator tied on the bucket, at full arm extension. How much more powerful do you need?
column12:
2. Swapping to XL motor will give a faster boom raise/lowering.
Fact: the XL motor is in fact slower than the M motor despite the superior torque. I've watched upgraded 8043 on Youtube, I can lower and raise the boom just as fast on the M motor. Unless you want to lift a big chunks of rock LOL and destroying the gears and LAs.
column13:
3. Alkalines are better because of higher voltage
Fact:
column14: The high ampere draw of this model will do MUCH better with high performance rechargeable Ni-MH AA batteries or the Lego 8878 LiPo battery. These batteries despite their lower voltage, gives&nbsp
column18: the hardworking M motors in this set.
column19: Verdict : This model is targeted more towards AFOLs, you need a basic understanding of mechanics to make this model perform well. Overall this is a great buy, and this 32 y.o. AFOL can't stop playing with his 8043 hahahaha.

column1: If you doubt the lifting power of the stock 8043 with the so called 'weak' M motors...please see this demo vid which I made earlier to show its lifting power.

oldlegopro,"2011-04-25T00:24:07.89Z","Very, Very cool technic set","

I had many lego sets as a kid, started off with space and city sets when I was very young and I had some the earliest Techic back in the late 70's early 80's. (too young for lego at this moment) My younger sister and her husband recently purchased the Deathstar. She said it was amazing! It got me thinking. Star wars lego not my cup of tea, but I bet they got some cool Technic's sets now that its 2011. column2:
and is looking for a challenge. Its a very realistic model excavator! The motorized action after some minor ajustments, it articulates well. My will be mostly for display but is a blast to drive around. It could be a little quicker. I will try the bulldozer this set makes. The 8043 is one awsome set! It has rekindled an old love for Lego.

",TRUE,5,5,5,3,4

mescalinum,"2011-08-18T10:53:23.017Z","great assortment of pieces for MOCs. a must have!","

rasikaa,"2011-09-12T00:01:41.397Z","Great set","Got this set for my son (to be honest, I wanted it). Had read most of the reviews on this set all over the net and thought of it being one of the best sets to get started with more advanced mechanics. When it came in, couldn't wait to get started. Completed building it with my son (5+) over two days as I wanted him to do most of the building.

The set is very complex. The gears, the joints, the mechanics, .... wow! It was a great design. Halfway through, you get lost with how the mechanics work as you build it from two different sides. But it has got the works. 4 motors, clutches, all types of gears, linear actuators, universal joints,... the list goes on. It is mind boggling to think how it was designed in the first place. Some of the connections that you put in early in the building are used only right at the end to join with another piece.

My son is still enjoying playing with it. I want build the model B, but hate to take it apart as he is enjoying it to the max. The 4 motors make it a bit noisy, but works like a charm. I will try to get some silicon grease on the gears and joints to make the movements a bit more smoother as someone had suggested in one of the reviews.
column2:
The batteries do drain down quickly as you have 4 motors driving (3 are used almost all the time). It is a good thing that the mode converter has an external lever as when the batteries run a bit dry, this tends to get a bit stuck down.
",TRUE,5,5,5,5,5

column1:

column1:
,TRUE,5,5,5,5,5 DrFrankenstein","2013-04-27T20:57:04.133Z","A modern classic","What can I say that hasn't been said before about this marvelous excavator model? Complex build - check. Tons of gears, electric components, and linear actuators - check. Amazing functionality with full remote control - check. Great looks and size - check. The list goes on and on. Let's just skip to the chase... Forget about 9398, 8258, 8297, 8285, or even 8110 and 8275. This is the king of all modern Technic flagships.

The excavator is a perfect balance of form and function. The only two (minor) complaints that people have in general, and I tend to agree with them, are about the speed of the functions and the size of the scoop. Beyond this, one would be hard-pressed to find fault with the model. The gears mechanism is a wonderfully complex case study of routing mechanical power to the actuators. The chassis operation through the turntable is ingenious. And the thing looks and works for the most part like a real excavator. It's a joy to build and brings a great sense of accomplishment when complete.

So, to sum it all up... This is a must have for any Technic fan. So, go, get it already.",TRUE,5,5,5,5,5

geoffpike,"2012-01-17T15:33:33.897Z","Just like the real excavator","Have just got into Lego Technic, after wife bought me Lego Unimog for christmas. Never had lego as a boy, now know what I missed.&nbsp
column2: <div>The 8043 excavator was a challenge but great fun to build, no real problems. The instructions are very clear and easy to follow.&nbsp
column3:
Operating it is even more fun, just love all the different actions, I regularly drive mini diggers and this model is just like the real thing to operate.
Will have to try and convert the Unimog to have radio control movement, so much more enjoyable to be able drive around the room.
All in all a very enjoyable project.
",FALSE,5,5,5,5,5

column1:
ptf,"2013-04-26T16:27:59.843Z","Probably the best Technic set ever","

The first set I bought after DA in 2012. Resisted 8421, then 8275, then 8265 and 8258 but this one was too much for me.

• build - superb gearbox and technical solutions makes it interesting and challenging building experience - (in my opinion better than 8275)
  • parts - lots of PF parts and gears + tracks (also better than 8275), very good base for MOCs
  • excellent A model ( even better when equipped with 42006 claw :) )
column2:
• excellent B model
  • playability - second to none (both models)

column1: • a little bit slow A model - but that's the way excavators move I guess

It is probably the best Technic set ever produced (ex aequo with 8110 Unimog), must have for every Technic fan. Too bad it is out of production now, so it gets more and more expensive.

",TRUE,5,5,5,5,5

odueck,"2012-08-12T14:13:19.693Z","Pricey, but an excellent fully-functional set","This is the first Technic set I have built in many, many years. As such, the vast majority of the parts were new to me so it was a very interesting build. It took me just over five hours to complete.

Unfortunately, I managed to make three mistakes. The first was minor, but too late to correct. It was not a functional problem though, so I kept building. The second was also minor and I was able to fix as soon as I caught it. The third was more major. I left out a gear which means I can't raise/lower the crane arm. So I will have to rebuild. But that's my own fault.

I love the design of the functionality of this set. The gearbox is incredibly intricate and it's crucial that you are careful to ensure all the gears work as they are supposed to.

My only disappointment with the functionality is that the actual back/forward movement of the crane is very slow. But that's a minor quibble.

This set is expensive at $249.99 CAD. I was able to get a relatively good deal by ordering from amazon.co.uk, but it can also be had for $200 at TRU which is fairly reasonable. The functionality certainly makes up for the high price.

All in all, this is a very impressive set.
",TRUE,5,5,5,5,4
Victor_c3,"2012-08-13T10:17:55.297Z","Most amazing set I've ever owned","
column2: FONT-FAMILY: 'Verdana','sans-serif'"">This is the second set I've bought since the 1990s, the other set being the 8421 (mobile crane) that I picked up in 2007. I have to say that lego technic has come a LONG way since my childhood and has made some pretty modest progression since even 2005. This set represents the pinnacle of what I'd expect lego to be. And, in short, this is by far the most amazing lego set I've ever owned.
FONT-FAMILY: 'Verdana','sans-serif'"">At first, I cringed at the idea of spending $200 (MSRP) on roughly 1100 pieces when I could have picked up a 2100 piece&nbsp
column3: 8110 (Unimog) for the same price. However, seeing that this set has been on the market for 2 years and it was on my ""wish list"", I figured I better pick it up while I could still find it from regular retailers online. I mentioned this in my review of the 8865 (test car), but when you adjust the price of the 8865 in 1990 (which was roughly $115 in 1990 [$187 in 2010 dollars], if I remember correctly) it is right in line with the 8043 - and you get a lot more bang for your buck with the 8043 with the 4 motors, 2 IR sender/receivers, a battery bot, two remotes, 4 linear actuators,... So, to actually issue an opinion, I believe you get a lot for your money with this model when you take this into consideration.

column2: FONT-FAMILY: 'Verdana','sans-serif'"">Almost every review that I've read&nbsp
column3: mentioned that the shovel is the one major aesthetic shortcoming of the model. Honestly, I think lego could have done better with a new piece, but the one that comes with the model&nbsp
column4: is just fine. Playing with the model firsthand, I didn't even really notice it.

column2: FONT-FAMILY: 'Verdana','sans-serif'"">The one thing that surprised me was just how strong the linear actuators were. I don't think&nbsp
column4: play that you could actually break a linear actuator.&nbsp
column5: Also, the motors themselves have a lot of power for being as small as they are and they definitely out perform the motors that I was playing with circa 1990.

column2: FONT-FAMILY: 'Verdana','sans-serif'"">Playability of this model is what I think makes it stand apart from anything that I've ever owned or played with. I didn't think the motors were underpowered by any means and all of the moving mechanisms were very robust. Sure, the vehicle doesn't move that fast and the arms could move a little faster, but you made this thing out of legos. If you want a toy that can move and dig like a real excavator and that you can put in a sandbox, go buy a purpose-built toy.&nbsp
column3: However, if you enjoy moderately complex lego models that you can put together and tweak yourself and then see how the functions work, this is the way to go. The fact that a lego model is being compared to a purpose-built toy by other reviewers above is very telling of the quality and design of lego products. If you can put something together yourself out of a pile of little plastic pieces and have it in any way comparable to a purpose built toy designed by engineers and built in a factory then&nbsp
column4: I think you have something very special.

column2: FONT-FAMILY: 'Verdana','sans-serif'"">Complexity and design has come a long ways since the models that I played with circa 1990. The gearbox and power transmission portion of the model, although not new (i.e. the Jennifer Clark model mentioned in another review) are a joy to put to together and to see how it works. I've seen/read a lot of complaints in the past over the move from studded to stud-less design. At first I disliked the stud-less design, but after playing with the newer models, I believe that you can pack a lot more functionality into a much smaller place and make mechanisms that you couldn't with studded pieces. This model is a perfect example of that.

FONT-FAMILY: 'Verdana','sans-serif'"">With this model I've notice more and more that lego is color coding more and more of their pieces. When I was playing with my legos circa 1990, all gears were grey, all axels were black, all pins were grey or black, bushings were grey, etc. However, now you have all even numbered axels are black, odd are grey, #2 axels are red, you have tan axels with stops, dark grey gears, light grey gears, tan gears,... At first I thought the colors were excessive, but after assembling the model and sifting through a sea of parts, the color coding really does help with the assembly. Additionally, when you are playing with the model, it is easier to follow the transmission of power through the model(s). So, I guess I like the color coding. It makes a lot of sense to me.

FONT-FAMILY: 'Verdana','sans-serif'"">The only thing I don't like are the panels and large pre-fabricated pieces like that. I'd rather make my own panels from a bunch of smaller pieces, but I suppose that a pre-fabricated panel is cheaper to produce (i.e. keeps the model half-way reasonably priced) and also is more robust (won't fall apart during play). However, as much as I don't like them, they aren't that bad.

FONT-FAMILY: 'Verdana','sans-serif'"">So, after writing all of this, what is my verdict? Pull the trigger and buy this model! It is a pleasure to build and a lot of fun to play with. I put this model together on a Saturday, played with it with my 4 year old daughter all day Sunday, and I disassembled it Monday so that I could repeat the process again.

column1:
Diego116,"2018-06-21T22:15:08.36Z","8043 Motorized Excavator - 2010 Technic Flagship Model ","

Excellent build and playability. With 2 controllers and 2 IR receivers. B-model which is a bulldozer is also superb. A very well though-out
column2: model by LEGO. One of the best sets in terms of value for money.
